G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and applicable Massachusetts landlord–tenant law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is an action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and related provisions, the Cambridge District Court has jurisdiction over this landlord–tenant dispute.

*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..proposition: As a matter of Massachusetts common law and statute, every residential tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and Defendant’s conduct must not substantially interfere with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the Premises.
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..support_reasoning: The court expressly recognizes that a lease carries an implied obligation that the lessor will refrain from acts that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises, framed in terms of ‘peaceful enjoyment’ and ‘beneficial enjoyment’ of the demised premises. While this is a commercial (dental office) tenancy and not expressly about a statute, the reasoning is stated in general common-law terms applicable to leases, and the case treats substantial landlord interference as violating the tenant’s rights to quiet enjoyment. Thus it supports the proposition as to an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and the requirement that landlord conduct not substantially interfere with use and enjoyment.
*Winchester v. O\u2019Brien*, 266 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … If a landlord authorizes acts to be done which cause substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises…the landlord is liable therefor.”

*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.raw_text: *Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.*, 340 Mass. 124 (1959)
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.proposition: As a matter of Massachusetts common law and statute, every residential tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and Defendant’s conduct must not substantially interfere with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the Premises.
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.case_name: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.support_reasoning: The case clearly recognizes and applies a covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so in the context of a commercial lease for business space on the fifth floor of a building. The court’s reasoning and holding concern business tenants and constructive eviction, not residential tenancies or any statutory rule governing residential leases. Thus, it supports the general principle that a landlord’s serious failure of essential services can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not stand for the specific proposition that every *residential* tenancy includes such an implied covenant under Massachusetts common law and statute.
*Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Co.relevant_excerpt: “Where tenants lease space on an upper floor of an urban building, as here, to conduct business enterprises, it is unrealistic to say that furnishing light, heat (in our climate), power, and elevator service does not go to the essence of what the landlord is to provide… Such a failure constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… and ‘enables the lessee to recover the damages caused to him thereby and also provides the lessee with the defense of ‘constructive eviction’ (if he removes from the premises).’”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord is liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord’s acts or omissions cause a substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G. L. c. 186, § 14 and clarifies the standard for landlord liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court states that liability arises where there is at least negligent conduct by the landlord, involving notice or reason to know of the problem and a failure to take appropriate corrective measures, and that such failure must cause an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This aligns with the proposition that a landlord is liable when their acts or omissions cause a substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures… the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord is liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord’s acts or omissions cause a substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that a landlord can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment without intending to do so, where substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment flows as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted. It applied that principle to find a breach (and constructive eviction) based on the landlord’s leasing and failure to control a noisy lounge that substantially deprived tenants of quiet enjoyment, thus directly supporting the stated proposition.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: "There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.... Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable."

*Rampersad v. Latalladi*, 23 Mass. App..proposition: As a matter of Massachusetts law, Plaintiff’s tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and Defendant also has express statutory obligations under G.L. c. 186, § 14 not to directly or indirectly interfere with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises.
*Rampersad v. Latalladi*, 23 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion is a domestic relations/tax allocation case and does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. Nowhere does the court discuss implied covenants of quiet enjoyment or statutory obligations concerning interference with a tenant’s use of premises. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for the stated Massachusetts landlord-tenant proposition.

*Sullivan v. Rent Control Bd. of Brookli.raw_text: *Sullivan v. Rent Control Bd. of Brookline*, 397 Mass. 738 (1986)
*Sullivan v. Rent Control Bd. of Brookli.proposition: As a matter of Massachusetts law, Plaintiff’s tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and Defendant also has express statutory obligations under G.L. c. 186, § 14 not to directly or indirectly interfere with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises.
*Sullivan v. Rent Control Bd. of Brookli.case_name: Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority Retirement Board
*Sullivan v. Rent Control Bd. of Brookli.support_reasoning: The opinion in Sullivan v. Rent Control Bd. of Brookline does not concern landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. It addresses suspension and retirement benefits of MBTA employees under G.L. c. 30, § 59, and the applicability of G.L. c. 32 and a pension agreement. Therefore it does not establish or discuss any implied covenant of quiet enjoyment or statutory quiet enjoyment obligations, and cannot support the proposition cited.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: A landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 does not require proof of malice; it is sufficient that the landlord’s conduct, or that of persons acting under the landlord’s authority, results in a substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that malicious or specifically intentional conduct is not required for liability for interference with quiet enjoyment. It explains that, after the 1973 amendment and in light of common-law quiet enjoyment principles, liability may be based at least on reckless conduct whose natural and probable consequence is substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. The opinion thus supports the proposition that proof of malice is unnecessary and that substantial interference resulting from the landlord’s conduct (or that of those under its authority) is sufficient.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “When § 14 was first enacted, both categories of prohibited conduct…were modified by the words ‘willfully or intentionally.’… In 1973, the statute was rewritten… The requirement of intentional conduct was retained for failure to provide essential services, but deleted from the quiet enjoyment clause… One natural inference from this amendment is that the Legislature meant to abrogate the requirement of specific intent to disturb quiet enjoyment… In sum, we hold that… [n]or must the tenant prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights, at least as long as the landlord’s conduct was reckless.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that persistent and substantial disturbances originating from activity within the landlord’s control, even if ostensibly lawful or serving a legitimate purpose, may constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment when they materially impair the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court holds that a landlord’s omissions can breach quiet enjoyment when they permit conditions that seriously interfere with tenants’ use of the premises, even though the landlord’s underlying activities (or inaction) are not themselves unlawful. The opinion explains that liability arises where serious interference with the tenancy is the “natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord did or failed to do, and it applies that principle to persistent drug-related disturbances in common areas under the landlord’s control. This directly supports the idea that substantial disturbances arising from activities within the landlord’s control may constitute a breach when they materially impair tenants’ beneficial use.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”}

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and a reasonable attorney’s fee.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.support_reasoning: The opinion directly quotes G.L. c. 186, § 14, stating that a landlord who interferes with quiet enjoyment “shall … be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” The court applies § 14 to Thomas’s counterclaim and holds that, upon a showing of violation, she is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees, thereby supporting the proposition about available remedies under the statute.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and a reasonable attorney’s fee.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion in Haddad v. Gonzalez is a Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court case, but it interprets and applies G.L. c. 93A and the warranty of habitability; it does not discuss or construe G.L. c. 186, § 14’s remedial scheme. The court nowhere states that a plaintiff is entitled to recover actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and a reasonable attorney’s fee under § 14. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the specific damages formulation attributed to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: To the extent applicable, the standards governing landlord liability for substantial interference with tenants’ rights and quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts are further reflected in cases such as *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005) (reaffirming protections for residential tenants), and *Board of Health of N. Adams v. Lewis*, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 161 (1986) (recognizing landlord responsibilities regarding conditions affecting habitability and use).
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition characterizes Jablonski as “reaffirming protections for residential tenants” and as reflecting standards governing landlord liability for substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. In this case, however, the Appeals Court affirms a finding of no breach of warranty of habitability and no breach of quiet enjoyment, emphasizing that not every Sanitary Code violation is actionable and that the landlord acted promptly. While the opinion recites the general standards for habitability and quiet enjoyment, its holding applies them to reject the tenant’s claims rather than to expand or particularly reinforce tenant protections, so it is a weak fit for the proposition as stated.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions.”

*Board of Health of N. Adams v. Lewis*,.raw_text: *Board of Health of N. Adams v. Lewis*, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 161 (1986)
*Board of Health of N. Adams v. Lewis*,.proposition: To the extent applicable, the standards governing landlord liability for substantial interference with tenants’ rights and quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts are further reflected in cases such as *Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005) (reaffirming protections for residential tenants), and *Board of Health of N. Adams v. Lewis*, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 161 (1986) (recognizing landlord responsibilities regarding conditions affecting habitability and use).
